video.title_en: Blackbody Radiation and the Ultraviolet Catastrophe

summary.text_en: At the PTR in Berlin, Otto Lummer and Ernst Pringsheim conducted a series of highly precise experiments to measure the spectrum of light emitted by a 'black body' (a perfect absorber/emitter) at different temperatures. Their data, perfected in 1899-1900, proved *definitively* that the best-available theory, 'Wien's Law', was *wrong* in the long-wavelength (infrared) region. This experimental 'failure' created a deep crisis for classical physics and provided the critical data Max Planck needed to formulate his revolutionary 'Quantum Hypothesis' (`planck_quantum_1900`).
key_points_en: Provided the most precise experimental data on black-body radiation
Used a 'cavity radiator' (Hohlraum) as a perfect black body
Proved Wien's Law fails at long wavelengths (infrared)
Provided the experimental basis for Planck's formula

story.text_en: In the late 19th century, physicists hunted for a formula to explain how hot objects glow. Willy Wien proposed a law in 1896 that worked *perfectly* for visible light (short wavelengths). Most thought the problem was solved. But Lummer and Pringsheim were rigorous experimentalists. They built special, temperature-controlled 'cavities' (blackened ceramic or platinum tubes) and painstakingly measured into the invisible 'infrared' spectrum. Their data showed a clear *deviation*â€”Wien's predicted curve completely failed in the infrared. It was this 'failure', this 'glitch' that classical physics could not explain, that forced their colleague Max Planck to invent the 'quantum' to make the math fit their data.

fun_facts.text_en: Their 'black body' was a hollow, blackened porcelain or platinum cylinder, electrically heated to over 1500Â°C. They observed the 'perfect' radiation that escaped from a tiny hole.

Planck and Lummer worked at the same institute (the PTR). The data flow was immediate. Lummer & Pringsheim presented their data to the Berlin Physical Society in October 1900; Planck was in the audience. Hours later, Planck had derived his new formula.

simple_explanation.text_en: Imagine you have a 'theoretical map' (Wien's Law) that perfectly predicts where treasure (light energy) is in 'Europe' (visible light). Lummer and Pringsheim were the first explorers to *actually go* to 'Asia' (infrared light). They came back and reported, 'The map is totally wrong in Asia!' The *new, accurate map* they brought back (their data) is what forced Max Planck (`planck_quantum_1900`) to throw out the old map and draw a completely new, quantum one.

applications.text_en: Their precise data served as the 'gold standard' that Planck's Law (`planck_quantum_1900`) *had* to match. Without this data, Planck's theory would have just been a hypothesis.

applications.text_en: Their precise work on radiation laws laid the foundation for 'optical pyrometers'â€”devices that measure the temperature of a hot object (like molten steel) by looking at its 'color'.

impact.text_en: Lummer and Pringsheim's experiment was the final nail in the coffin of classical physics. It was one of the greatest experimental achievements of the 19th century, proving by irrefutable data that the old theories had failed, and providing the *necessary* experimental foundation for Max Planck to launch the quantum revolution. It is the perfect example of how precise *experiment* forces theoretical *revolution*.

influenced_by.contribution_en: Gustav Kirchhoff (who first proposed the theoretical concept and challenge of the 'black body')
Willy Wien (whose 'Wien's Law' was the theory they were testing and (ultimately) disproved)

influenced.contribution_en: Max Planck (whose 'quantum hypothesis' was invented *specifically* to fit Lummer & Pringsheim's precise data)

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Lummer and Pringsheim's precise measurements were the 'brute facts' that forced physics into the quantum age.

quiz.question_en: Lummer & Pringsheim's black-body experiments proved that 'Wien's Law' was incorrect in which part of the spectrum?
quiz.explanation_en: Wien's Law worked very well for short wavelengths (visible and UV), but Lummer & Pringsheim's precise measurements showed it failed badly in the long-wavelength (infrared) region. This 'infrared deviation' is what forced Planck to create his new theory.
